speaker: UI
text: the method that we usually use in the user interface design is that we need to look at what people like and what people don't like about existing products .

speaker: UI
text: So , in our case , existing remote controls .

speaker: UI
text: And then , what the good ideas are ,

speaker: UI
text: and what the bad ideas are ,

speaker: UI
text: and why they're bad and good ,

speaker: UI
text: We seem to have intuitions about why things are good or things are bad ,

speaker: UI
text: but when you look , technically , at how it works , sometimes that's not the case .

speaker: UI
text: Then we need to decide what functionalities we really want to keep ,

speaker: UI
text: 'cause that'll feed into both Ed's work and Christine's work .

speaker: UI
text: Um and then what the remote control should look like ,

speaker: UI
text: obviously , once we've got a good idea of what the functionalities are .

speaker: UI
text: in terms of the functionalities that we need , you obviously need to be able to turn the T_V_ on and off .

speaker: UI
text: You need to change channels , both by directly going to a specific channel or by channel surfing .

speaker: UI
text: You need to be able to control the volume

speaker: UI
text: and then control any menus on the T_V_ to regulate contrast or whatever .

speaker: UI
text: the problems that people have expressed is that there's too many buttons on remote controls , in general .

speaker: UI
text: The buttons <disfmarker> it's not clear what they're supposed to do .

speaker: UI
text: Um often , you need to know specific button sequences <vocalsound> to get certain functionalities done ,

speaker: UI
text: um which you don't necessarily always remember , especially if it's a functionality that you don't use very often .

speaker: UI
text: And that the buttons are too small .

speaker: UI
text: where here on the left-hand side , you can see a remote control that has lots and lots of buttons .

speaker: UI
text: The buttons , in a lot of cases , are tiny .

speaker: UI
text: but the labels don't necessarily tell you too much .

speaker: UI
text: Whereas , on the other side , you have a much simpler remote control

speaker: UI
text: that I think basically has the minimum functionalities <vocalsound> that are needed .

speaker: UI
text: And it sort of looks simpler and just less imposing when you first look at it .

speaker: UI
text: So , I would be inclined to go sort of towards this , in terms of design , rather than this .

speaker: UI
text: And if there's specific functionalities that require more buttons , then we can figure out how to do it with existing um buttons .

speaker: UI
text: So my personal preferences are to keep the number of buttons to a limit , or to a minimum ,

speaker: UI
text: make frequently used buttons bigger and more strategically placed , so like the on button being really obvious one , the channel changing and the volume ,

speaker: UI
text: and to keep the design basically sleek and simple .

speaker: UI
text: Which , I think ties into what Christine and Ed have both said fairly reasonably .

speaker: UI
